conclusion: Objects A and B start moving in a straight line simultaneously and from the same location at rest.
The relationship between the acceleration of the objects and time is shown in the problem diagram, where t2 = 2t1.
Determine if objects A and B have the same velocity at time t1.
The image shows a graph with acceleration on the vertical axis and time on the horizontal axis. Two lines represent the motion of objects A and B.
Object A starts with a horizontal line indicating no acceleration, while object B has a diagonal line indicating increasing acceleration over time.
A shaded region highlights the acceleration from time t1 to t2, where t2 = 2t1.
Identify Acceleration: Object A has no acceleration, while object B has increasing acceleration.
Calculate Velocity: Velocity is calculated by integrating acceleration over time. Since A has no acceleration, its velocity remains zero at all times.
Compare Velocities at t1: For object A, the velocity at t1 is zero because it was at rest and had no acceleration.
For object B, the velocity at t1 is positive because it has been accelerating.
Conclusion: Since object A has zero velocity and object B has a positive velocity at time t1, they do not have the same velocity at that time.
